title: 109_s781
content: The Act titled "Right-to-Ride Livestock on Federal Land Act of 2005" allows the use of pack and saddle animals on public land. The Act "Right-to-Ride Livestock on Federal Land Act of 2005" permits the use of pack and saddle animals on National Park System land, preserving historical traditions. The Secretary of the Interior must manage the land to facilitate access for these animals. The Secretary may implement a proposed reduction in the use of pack and saddle stock animals on National Park System land after complying with the full review process required by the National Environmental Policy Act. This subsection does not authorize the Secretary to refuse permits for new use of these animals or limit their authority in managing the land. The Secretary of the Interior's authority to impose temporary emergency closures of trails for pack and saddle stock animals is limited. The use and access of pack and saddle animals on Bureau of Land Management land must be preserved and facilitated. The Bureau of Land Management land with a historical tradition of pack and saddle stock animals must remain open for their use, with limitations requiring a full review process for any proposed reductions in access. The Environmental Policy Act of 1969 does not authorize the Secretary to refuse permits for pack and saddle stock animal use without following resource management plans. It also allows for emergency closures and special permits, without creating a preference for any recreational use on Bureau of Land Management land. The National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966 is amended to preserve and facilitate the use of pack and saddle animals on System land with a historical tradition of such use. The National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966 is amended to ensure that System land described in subparagraph (A) remains open for the use of pack and saddle stock animals. The Secretary may only implement a reduction in access after complying with the National Environmental Policy Act. This amendment does not authorize the Secretary to deny permits for new use of pack and saddle stock animals. The amendment limits the Secretary's authority to impose temporary closures or issue special permits for pack and saddle stock animals on System land. It also prevents creating a preference for one recreational use without considering the unit's purpose. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 is amended to redesignate section 16 as section 17 and insert a new section after section 15. "Section 16 addresses the use and access of pack and saddle animals." The Secretary of Agriculture manages National Forest System land to preserve and allow the use of pack and saddle stock animals, including in wilderness areas and national monuments. Access for these animals is generally allowed, but reductions require compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The Secretary of Agriculture manages National Forest System land to preserve and allow the use of pack and saddle stock animals, including in wilderness areas and national monuments. Compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 is required for new use permits. The section does not authorize refusal of permits without following resource management plans, allows temporary closures, and does not create a preference for one recreational use. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture must define "historical tradition of the use of pack and saddle stock animals" within 120 days of the Act's enactment.
